You certainly don't need THAT.

>what's so hated about
>grouping them all in the same method, though?

If I run three tests, I want JUnit to report 3 runs, not 1. It will eventually confuse someone at a key moment. It always does. It's like trying to remember a lie: eventually it catches up with you -- it's easier to tell the truth from the beginning.

>sure you're running
>multiple tests in one test method, but it is still easy to track
>specific problems down since you get the stack trace.

True enough, but it doesn't give me an accurate picture of the number of tests in the system.

Simple solution:

public void testTwoIntegers() {
// use a and b from fixture
}

public static Test suite() {
int[][] testData = new int[][] {
{Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue},
{Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue},
...
};

TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
for (int i = 0; i < testData.length; i++) {
suite.addTest(new IntegerTest(testData[i][0], testData[i][1]);
}

return suite;
}

public IntegerTest(int a, int b) {
super("testTwoIntegers"); // leverage TestCase reflection to run test method 'testTwoIntegers'
// set fixture for test
this.a = a;
this.b = b;
}

An alternative, with less magic, is to override runTest().

public void testTwoIntegers(int a, int b) {
// test implementation
}

public static Test suite() {
int[][] testData = new int[][] {
{Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue},
{Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue},
...
};

TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
for (int i = 0; i < testData.length; i++) {
suite.addTest(new IntegerTest() {
protected void runTest() {
testTwoIntegers(testData[i][0], testData[i][1]);
}
});
}

return suite;
}

I prefer the first because it avoids a bunch of anonymous subclasses.
